Google might regret this data leak cover-up

Google will shut down its ill-fated Google Plus social network over a security flaw that exposed the private data of up to 500,000 users.

Shira Ovide of Bloomberg Opinion argues that the decision was unwise:

If the company had disclosed the Google Plus problem in March, it would have been a big deal but not a crisis.
The vulnerability revealed the email address, occupation, gender and age of the users to 438 third-party applications via online programming interfaces.
The company made the call amid Facebook’s Cambridge Analytica scandal, when it saw how bad public blowback over data security could be.
(An internal memo seen by the WSJ warned of “immediate regulatory interest” if the company went public.)
And it avoided a lawsuit over accusations it had illegally tracked 4.4 million iPhone users in Britain.
This cover-up, however, makes the Google Plus digital-security problem so much worse.
